title: Opinion: Eagles' humbling loss to Cowboys shows changes are needed
text:
CLOSE Lane Johnson, Fletcher Cox and Carson Wentz after the Eagles' 37-10 loss to the Dallas Cowboys. Martin Frank, The News Journal

ARLINGTON, Texas – There are defining moments in every season when a team can either pull it together or break apart.

The Eagles are at one of those moments.

They were humbled and humiliated in so many ways in their 37-10 loss to the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday night. This came one week after the same thing happened against the Vikings.

In those two games, the Eagles have been outscored 75-30.

"There are no excuses," right tackle Lane Johnson said. "It's make or break time. We'll find out what we're made of moving forward here in the next few weeks."

So far, the results aren't encouraging.

More: 32 things we learned from Week 7 of the 2019 NFL season

NFL Week 7 winners, losers: Aaron Rodgers now in MVP race; Mitchell Trubisky looks lost

The Eagles already endured a week when an anonymous player criticized the offense and quarterback Carson Wentz, as well as general manager Howie Roseman, for not making a trade for cornerback Jalen Ramsey.

The Eagles already tried shaking things up last week. They released Zach Brown, a starting linebacker, after he mouthed off about Vikings quarterback Kirk Cousins, in addition to his mediocre at best play.

And head coach Doug Pederson made his "sort of" guarantee for a victory.

Then the Eagles played even worse against the Cowboys.

Pederson was asked if this was his worst loss in his 3 1/2 seasons as head coach.

"It's either one or two, yes," he said.

When that happens, changes can't be too far behind.

"Putting out a (bad) performance like that is something we can't do," Johnson said. "Moving forward, there's going to be a lot of stuff changing. Maybe players, maybe a lot of stuff changing, I don't know. I've been in this business for a long time, and I know when stuff doesn't go right, there are changes to be made."

That's especially true when there are signs of surrender.

That perhaps was the most troubling sign, both on offense and defense.

Early in the fourth quarter, Carson Wentz threw a ball deep down the field to wide receiver Nelson Agholor, who had gotten behind his defender. It appeared that Agholor didn't extend his arms to make a play on the ball, which fell incomplete.

In the grand scheme of things, it wouldn't have made a difference other than to make the score a little more respectable. Still, Wentz's reaction was telling because typically the quarterback will take the blame, whether it's warranted or not.

"I thought we had a touchdown when I threw it," Wentz said. "I didn’t see the end result. I was on the ground, so I didn’t get a chance to see. But when I threw it, I thought we had a good one there. But I gotta make a better throw, obviously."

Agholor, meanwhile, gave his version of the play.

“I was trying to get open,” he said. "I was hauling tail, making a move on the safety, using the space that I had to run across the field and I was running. And by the time I was trying to track it, the ball was already at a position. I wish I had been able to get there. But I don’t know what happened."

Did he lose it in the lights?

“I made a move on a guy and I’m starting to run to my landmark and I get closer and I’m seeing it low in trajectory, so it is what it is," he said. "I can’t really explain it.”

Agholor is not one to give up. But he does seem to have trouble tracking deep balls, an area that DeSean Jackson, who missed his fifth straight game with an abdominal injury, thrives at.

That was hardly the Eagles' only problem.

The defense had no chance against the Cowboys. Dallas had a 14-0 lead six minutes into the game after two turnovers led to easy touchdowns. Malcolm Jenkins got run over by Ezekiel Elliott on one TD, Orlando Scandrick waved at Tavon Austin on another and the penalties were omnipresent.

It was 27-7 at halftime, the second straight game in which the Eagles allowed at least 24 points in the first half.

"It's (expletive) embarrassing," cornerback Rasul Douglas said. "We weren't solid on defense. We turned the ball over on offense ... Come on, man. You can't win like that."

And the Eagles won't, not until something changes.

"What has to change is we've got to roll our sleeves up and go to work," Pederson said. "We've got to figure out what's going on. We've got nine games left. It's going to start with me. I'm going to own this one for the football team ... We've got the guys in the locker room to get it fixed. I know that, and I still have a lot of faith in them, a lot of trust, and we'll get it fixed."

There is plenty to fix.

Johnson described the problems on offense: "There was no run game, no pass game, any rhythm. You saw that. No rhythm. No consistency."

Tight end Zach Ertz was just as frustrated. He didn't have a reception until the fourth quarter, and ended up with just two for 38 yards. Ertz set a record for receptions by a tight end last season with 116. He's on pace for about 80 this season.

"Tonight was embarrassing, one of the most embarrassing games I've ever been a part of in Philly, a pitiful performance," Ertz said. "We’re gonna see what the character of this team is. That's the bottom line.

"This feeling kills me ... It’s tough right now the way this team is playing.”

It doesn't get easier. The Eagles are on the road against the Buffalo Bills, at 5-1, next Sunday. Then they have three straight home games against the Bears, Patriots and Seahawks, all playoff teams last season.

"What are we going to do? How are we going to respond?" defensive end Brandon Graham said. "Are we going to tank? Because this is going to define our season.

"I have seen this thing play out so many different ways. We get healthy, we get people back, we will be alright."

That Graham is even asking those questions is troubling enough.

description: The Philadelphia Eagles are at a crossroads in their season after a loss to the Dallas Cowboys. Can they keep it from falling apart?
